data.title: should fixes #1284 (KinematicBody .move() crash)
data.body:
I could reproduce the crash described in #1284 only with 32bits versions of godot.

The test scene contains a Plane collision shape, and a kinematicsbody with a Sphere collision shape.

The crash occurs into `CollisionSolverSW::solve_distance_plane()` on line 299 when `p_shape_A` is a `PlaneShapeSW` object and when `p_shape_B` is a `MotionShapeSW` object, because `int support_count;` is not initialized by default, and because `MotionShapeSW::get_supports()` does not change `support_count` once passed as referenced parameter, and if the default value of `support_count` is greater than the length of `supports[16]`.

I don't know if it is the good way to fix it because i'm not skilled ennough with the physics server inner working, but this fix prevents the crash and the test-scene seems to work correctly.

data.title: tooltip placement incorrect from a scroll-area
data.body: Any tool-tips generated by a control that is inside a scroll-area appear on the screen global position based on their position inside the scroll-area. That is, if you have a scroll-area at 100, 100 and a control at 10, 10 within that scroll area, then the control's tool-tip will appear at 10, 10 on the screen, not 110, 110 as they should.

data.title: Ref cast to pointer does not implement proper const correctness
data.body:
In trying to bind some c++ functions in a module, I notice that when a function takes a `const Ref<T>&` parameter, taking the address of it returns a `const T*` where as it should return a `T*`.

If the current behaviour is wanted, it should take a parameter of `const Ref<const T>&` which would represent a constant reference to a constant object.

I can't think of any other way to pass a reference to a variable in as a parameter without making a copy of a `Ref` which requires a atomic operation.

I would be happy to submit a pull request if this is something that would be merged.

data.title: Undo "Align with view" doesn't work as expected
data.body: In a 3D scene, when you click on a camera and do "Align with view" (Ctrl+Shift+F), then you undo the command (Ctrl+Z), the camera's position doesn't restore properly.

data.title: Mesh splitting to reduce memory consumption by morphing+skeleton
data.body:
Skinning buffer for meshes with skeleton tends to be enormously large. Some optimization like mesh splitting during import is required for more effective memory usage.

Example: Hman mesh controlled by skeleton and a few small morphs, mesh size 23K verts, consumes 8MB RAM.

data.title: 3D and 2D Ragdoll setup should be simplified
data.body:
One can't imagine more tedious and gruesome task in current godot than setting up ragdolls.
It is just about copying physic bodies transform to bone poses, but it is very hard to make proper setup.
There is a lot of grey areas here, especially in 3d - what about leaf bones and bone offset calculations?
How to properly setuup proxy-doll of physics bodies having skeleton? yes, there are offsets for all except leaf bones, and you can setup loop in fixed process to copy transforms, but there are a lot of not
so visible problems, like how to set proper positions to RigidBodies to copy skeleton structure? How to handle leaf bones transforms? How to select proper joints? How to limit axis otations on joints?

This all requires some wizad-type class, which should set up ragdoll automatically, havin skeleton and additional parameters. Yes, you can do it by hand, but it consumes enormous amounts of time. And this feature is something for Godot could be proud of
....

data.title: BoneAttachment doesn't work as intended
data.body:
BoneAttachment is not copying bone position, as it is expected,
but is offset from actual bone. Also, offsetting BoneAttachment doesn't help at all.
I can use bone's Transform, but it is workaround, not a fix...

Also BoneAttachment should always be a parent of Skeleton and manipulates its children,
which looks a bit unnatural and unflexible. I'd add some node which behaves more like Joint...
This way it makes possible to have parent scenes to have nodes attached to child's skeleton,
which is more flexible. So, I think ability to select skeleton in node is essential.

data.title: Modal dialog still shows hover states
data.body:
I'm creating a modal dialog, as per the instructions in https://github.com/okamstudio/godot/wiki/tutorial_pause

This works great, in that I can't interact with controls outside the nodes I've set to work even when paused, but I still see hover changes in buttons that should be paused!

data.title: Fix isometric demo
data.body: Isometric demo columns move around, trying to get on pixel-boundaries, so I set them to have integer positions (thanks to Voidburn for pointing out the effect that was occurring).

data.title: fix get joystick name from registry on some systems
data.body: Updated to reflect the possibility of OEMName being in current_user instead of local_machine

data.title: Console shows trio of errors on opening Godot.
data.body:
![godot errors](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10081256/6365250/8d2d9674-bc79-11e4-92c8-3a0f0baf3ccd.jpg)
The console spits this out right when the Win64 dev. build is opened and the project list is displayed. The errors themselves don't cause any bugs, but just to make sure they don't become real bugs down the line.

Verified on Windows 7, I hope you would consider it good practice to report things like these.

data.title: [Visual Shader Editor] normal data output for 'global' space (and other types)
data.body:
I reason I argue for the change is because I don't know what use people may have for the current 'normal' output data which is view dependent, my idea of making the normal data so that it is global would allow it to have numerous use cases, especially for terrain.

What it can enable for terrain for instance is that it could then be used as a slope-based mask for textures, so steep slopes and overhangs are rocky and flat areas are grassy. On high-elevation maps, you could make it so the flat areas have snow.

Another thing to possible add (not mentioned in the title), is to have a second new output for normal data in space local to the object (for objects that might rotate).

Thirdly, it would also be good to have a third new output that colors the mesh based on the angle of the normal to the camera (for fresnal effects). Finally, one should go through what it available as data outputs right now and see if there's any that may not have much of an actual use (or no one plans to use and see if that can be taken out), just to make sure we have a nice list of outputs that have genuine and expansive uses for users.

data.title: Duplicate made by accident, please close.
data.body: Please close this duplicate, I didn't know this page on Google Chrome had a 'post it' hotkey and it submitted the issue before I was done typing.

data.title: COLLADA load morph target normals
data.body: if the file has normals use them!

data.title: Fixes platform/windows/detect.py
data.body:
- fixes issue #1298 and #1344 : under windows, too long `ar` command lines are now split into several smaller command lines.
- fixes issue #1285 : under linux, cross compiling with Mingw-w64 now generates actual 64bits EXE.
- `MINGW32_PREFIX` and `MINGW64_PREFIX` environment variables are also available for Windows.
- started to clean-up the remains of previous hacks and workarounds.
- added some documentation into the script.

data.title: get_stylebox("myStyle") doesn't always get the correct type.
data.body:
An example...

Say I made a progress bar, and I gave it my own style using the "newStyleBoxFlat" entry.

Now say I fetch the bar node using GDscript and used this code...

var Style = myBar.get_stylebox("myFlatStyle")
print(Style)

The print will give me "StyleBoxTextured:#" when it should be saying "StyleBoxFlat:#", as a result, I cannot change the color because the function for that is only for flat styles and the engine thinks I'm using the Textured type..

This shouldn't be too hard to fix I think, thanks.

data.title: 2D Light Multiplier
data.body: Currently you have to set the light strength via a texture. But sometimes you want the light even be brighter. Therefore it would be great to have a mutiplier for each light. This would help to make lights even brighter, or less bright.

data.title: Add a "Plugins" or "Tools" menu option
data.body: Since godot features can be extended by plugins, later the editor will have no space for plugin buttons. So please add a Tools menu option in the editor itself. So that all plugin developers can add their menu items(may be categorized) into it.

data.title: [Request (Visual Shader Editor)]; Add generic mix node with fac. input
data.body:
I ask because when looking through at the available options for combining textures, it seems like a strange omission to not have the ability to just do a plain mix that can then use a texture or vertex colors as the factor (in a single node at least).

I can see the proposal being done in two ways, you add a fac. input to the color ops. node along with a new 'mix' blending option or you make a separate node type just for plain mixing.

Hope you find it a good idea.

data.title: Visual Shader Editor; Certain shaders break on project load.
data.body:
An example of this is in this file
http://www.mediafire.com/download/ij4zgoaqracxfps/Texture.zip

And this image
![broken_shader](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10081256/6336345/98354304-bb67-11e4-8dce-b15272867672.jpg)

---

Open the file and you'll notice what appears to be a texture mapped to a rectangular object, but here's the thing...

Open the exp_shader file from the resource browser and take a look at the node tree, you will find that originally, it was using the RGB channels of the vertex color data to blend together three textures. However, it seems that this setup only works if you don't exit out of the project after creating, or otherwise you get the broken result as seen when the file is re-opened.

This was verified using a Win64 machine using an ATI 9xxx GPU, using a bleeding edge Feb23 64 big MingW build from the Godot sourceforge page. If this can be fixed, that would be good, thanks.

data.title: Wrong command in wiki
data.body: On this page: https://github.com/okamstudio/godot/wiki/compiling_windows#compiling , under the section compiling, the command for installing the needed packages says "ming32" instead of "mingw32"

data.title: More intuitive controls and operations in the new visual shader editor
data.body:
Namely, the short list of things I would like to see added to Godot's node window functionality
- Multi Select / Multi Move
- Duplicate (with noodles within the selection intact)
- ~~Zoom in / Zoom out~~ (*bugsquad edit: already done*)
- Option to have newly created nodes appear in the middle of the visible part of the workspace rather than in the middle of the node area

It's a bit basic right now, and working within the window tends to be a slow process when you only have basic controls available, it would be nice to speed things up a bit.

data.title: Export; Newer iterations of Godot won't import Collada UV's.
data.body:
The issue being...

If I download the newest available build of Godot (the sourceforge page has one from Feb 11th), and bring in a new Collada file, that version of Godot will not be able to read the UV coordinates of the object resulting in any texture being scaled down to infinity.

I have verified this by using both the official and the dev. version of the Better Collada exporter with the new build of Godot and by using the dev. version with 1.0 official. 1.0 official imports the coordinates as it should while the dev. build doesn't.

This doesn't affect models in game files already made, just new models, hope this can soon be fixed.

data.title: Place big input node automatically when creating new node material
data.body:
I ask this because one may not notice right away how to get a lot of needed material information to create a fully functional shader using the visual shader node, as the icon gives the impression that it's just a text field to use a custom variable (or some other basic data node) as opposed to a full-fledged output list with all the needed info.

What doesn't help is that the output node is placed in the editor automatically, but the big input node is not. You might want to consider having that node in the editor to start with as well so people know exactly that they have the basic information they need.

data.title: Sprite3D Billboard isn't work when used Material Override
data.body: If do that sprite will not show image.

data.title: Upload dev builds please
data.body:
I think we would benefit from having debug engine and templates uploaded somewhere whenever you push to master (or at least daily if you push more frequently on a day). Don't think there is a reason to upload release versions except for official releases though.

Building takes quite a while and is fiddly for some platforms, but there are a lot of us needing to use them...

data.title: Support Android immersive mode
data.body: Basically a copy of: https://www.assetstore.unity3d.com/en/#!/content/16852

data.title: add_color function of Surfacetool class doesn't work
data.body:
Setting a color doesn't work, it always displays as white.

```
extends MeshInstance

func _ready():

    var surface = SurfaceTool.new()
    surface.begin(Mesh.PRIMITIVE_TRIANGLE_STRIP)

    #Top
    surface.add_color(Color(1, 0, 0))
    surface.add_normal(Vector3(0, 1, 0))
    surface.add_vertex(Vector3(1, 0, 0))

    surface.add_color(Color(1, 0, 0))
    surface.add_normal(Vector3(0, 1, 0))
    surface.add_vertex(Vector3(1, 0, 1))

    surface.add_color(Color(1, 0, 0))
    surface.add_normal(Vector3(0, 1, 0))
    surface.add_vertex(Vector3(0, 0, 0))

    var mesh = surface.commit()

    set_mesh(mesh)
```

data.title: Support Mesh-based particles in 3D
data.body:
Currently only simple billboard (flat texture) particles are supported. Would be nice to have a method of creating mesh-based particles (especially if more primitives, like spheres and cubes are added, as requested by #1381)

Is there a plan to implement mesh-based particles any time soon or should I just write a script for it?

data.title: StringName/Nodepath works with single quote only
data.body:
The documentation says:
Hello, Hi   Strings
@"Node/Label"   Node Path or StringName

However, @"whatever" gives an EOL error. @'whatever' does work as expected. Either docs should be fixed or, ideally, @ should not care about the type of quotes used.
